quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Logical Operators[/h1]

[b]Logical [/b]Operators, also known as [b]Boolean [/b]Operators, evaluate the expression and return [b]true [/b]or [b]false[/b].

The table below explains the logical operators ([b]AND[/b], [b]OR[/b], [b]NOT[/b]). [img id="2749" width="100%"]

quizzes.question: Logical NOT returns true, if:
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Logical Operators [/h1]

In the following example, we have connected two Boolean expressions with the [b]AND [/b]operator.[code format="js" codeId="657"](4 > 2) && (10 < 15)[/code]
For this expression to be [b]true[/b], both conditions must be [b]true[/b].
- The first condition determines whether 4 is greater than 2, which is [b]true[/b]. 
- The second condition determines whether 10 is less than 15, which is also [b]true[/b]. 
Based on these results, the whole expression is found to be [b]true[/b].

[h2]Conditional (Ternary) Operator[/h2]
Another JavaScript conditional operator assigns a value to a variable, based on some condition.
[b]Syntax:[/b] [code format="js" ]variable = (condition) ? value1: value2 [/code]
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="js" codeId="658"]var isAdult = (age < 18) ? "Too young": "Old enough";[/code]
If the variable [i]age [/i]is a value below 18, the value of the variable [i]isAdult [/i]will be "Too young". Otherwise the value of [i]isAdult [/i]will be "Old enough".
[note]Logical operators allow you to connect as many expressions as you wish.[/note]
